reviewText: I already knew Dave Chapelle was funny, but what was a real eye-opener for me in this movie was what a generous spirit he has. I don't mean generous as in "he paid for this whole concert/film project himself" (although he did), I mean generous as in "he has a genuine interest and affection for ALL types of people."Because of Chapelle's affability, one is disinclined to criticize BLOCK PARTY for cutting away from the musical acts to Dave as he ambles around a Brooklyn day-care center, or hangs out with an Ohio marching band. Eventually, the party starts. Now parties are fun to go to, but party movies are almost always lame. BLOCK PARTY is the exceptional exception to the rule.Here are some quick hits on some of the performers: Ahmir-Khalib Thompson (articulate, and a great drummer), Kanye West (really good on  his solo number), Mos Def (I love that guy), Talib Kweli (raps so fast, he sort of loses the flow), Dead Prez (had never heard them, now I want to hear more), Erykah Badu (wig blows off), Jill Scott (she kicks!), the Roots (I know they're really good, but it doesn't come across that well), the Fugees (good).
summary: An Exceptional Exception to the Rule

reviewText: I really enjoyed seeing a different side to Dave. I agree with most reviewers that this movie is not really funny by any means, but it gave me a new light to the comedian. There is a serious and very respectable side to Mr. Chappelle and i feel he is the next big comedian to hit our generation. I never knew Chappelles understanding and respect for jazz music and his dedication to learning Round Midnight by the great Monk. He brings up almost "almost" a philosophical way of looking at how comedians and musicians intertwine. I enjoyed it, the replay value isn't there though. There was not enough footage of the music performances. It could have been set up into 2 parts i felt, The Concert, and than his little documentary, but it wasnt set up like that. Overall i gained some respect for Dave after seeing this

reviewText: For all its benefits, one of the things that modern technology has really put the kibosh on, unfortunately, is the concert movie.These days, fans can see their favorite musicians on so many small screens -- on cable TV, the Internet, even their cellphones -- that there really isn't much of a demand for old-school, 1970s and '80s-era big-screen music experiences in the style of "Woodstock," "The Last Waltz," Led Zeppelin's "The Song Remains the Same" or the Talking Heads' excellent "Stop Making Sense."Leave it to comedian Dave Chappelle, then, to bankroll something as unexpected as "Block Party," a film that fits right into that "back-in-the-day" cinematic category.In September 2004, (before his famous flight to Africa) Chappelle set up a stage in Brooklyn's Bed-Stuy neighborhood and filmed a concert that featured hip-hop and R&B; acts including Kanye West, the Roots, Erykah Badu and a reunion of the Fugees.Like the 1973 documentary "Wattstax" (to which "Block Party" pays unabashed homage), the film focuses as much on the audience and the show's locale as it does the musicians onstage, and Chappelle wanders through it all, riffing in his edgy drawl that's part hip alley cat, part lunatic. His comic bit about James Brown's routine of commanding "hornshouts" from his band, those little blasts of instrumental punctuation, is one of the funniest scenes in any comedy in a long while.Director Michel Gondry, who animated the White Stripes with Lego blocks and made "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," filmed the concert and peppers the movie with great little random, textural bits: Chappelle reflecting on jazz great Thelonious Monk or talking to the woman who supervised the day care center attended by the late Biggie Smalls; Wyclef Jean firing up a group of kids; a blissfully happy young couple on their way to the show.There's a lot of music in the movie, too, and while "Block Party" isn't as much of a roof-raiser as one might expect (the heaviest it gets is West performing "Jesus Walks" with the Central State University marching band), the vibe is mostly funk and jazzy riffs, surprisingly mellow and accessible.If the film has a drawback it's that, as in "Wattstax," the performance footage is constantly intercut with interviews. It's great to see the Fugees together again, but odd when Gondry cuts into their number to show ... musicians commenting on how great it is to see the Fugees together again.But that's a minor quibble. For the most part, "Block Party" is an exuberant, inspiring surprise and a welcome wintertime blast of music and comedy. And it's especially cool that Chappelle has brought the concert movie back to American multiplexes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In September of 2004 comedienne Dave Chapelle organized a huge block party which included performances with acclaimed members of the hip-hop and R&B; community. Fans of the funnyman will be glad to know that Dave Chapelle's Block Party is more than just a good concert.Dave heads back to his home state of Ohio and rounds up a diverse group of community members and hands out golden tickets. With the tickets the recipients will be able to ride a chartered bus to New York, stay in a hotel room and attend the block party concert. Dave heads to local stores, the streets and Central State University to find people willing to make the trip.In New York Mos Def, Talib Kweli, Common, Dead Prez, Erykah Badu, The Roots, Jill Scott, Kanye West (with John Legend) and Dave's special guests The Fugees are awaiting to perform at a once in a lifetime concert.The stage is set and the viewer get's the unique opportunity to watch this concert event unfold from start to finish. The performances are all great and even though or rained part of the day the crowd was unphased and the performances are awesome. The bad part is that it seems like you only get bits and pieces of the performances but the DVD does have the option to watch the block party with extended musical performances.Dave Chapelle is best known for being a comedienne so Chapelle fans will be pleased to know that there are plenty of funny moments in Dave Chapelle's Block Party, it's not just Dave hosting a concert.
summary: Much more than just Dave hosting a concert

reviewText: I first would like to say that I am a huge fan of Dave Chappelle and all the recording artists in the movie. So it is a given that I enjoyed the movie. I love the fact that Dave used his popularity to make a movie basically about the great music that he likes. The artists in this movie do not get play on MTV, they do not sell millions of records. They make good hip hop music and are overlooked by all most all media. Media has potrayed all hip hop to be guns drugs and putting down women. That is a part of the culture, but there are people like Kanye West, Mos Def, Common, Talib Kweli, and the Roots who make great music and are not respected as much as they be because most people that do not listen to hip hop cannot tell the difference between Common and the Yin Yang Twins. I hope that not just people who like Hip Hop go to this movie but all people go just to see this side of hip hop that mainstream media has not shown the public. This movie is very funny I think Dave is funny basically not matter what he does. There are some great momments where Dave just speaks very candid about his feelings on how the music in the film can help people and also bring people togeather. The Fugees getting togeather was a great end to the film Lauryn Hill is an amazing artist and hopefully they will release new music soon. It was hard for me to sit in my chair and watch Talib Kweli perform "Get By". My only complaint is that the performances are often cut into interviews and backstage stuff. I would have like to have been able to hear the entire song at some parts but this is a minor complaint. Overall, I suggest everybody see this movie you may not like the actual music, but after watching the movie you will realize how powerful hip hop music is.

reviewText: This movie is not funny at all. The commercials and advertising make it out ot be this hilarious full length movie and it is not. Dave doesn't really crack too many jokes in the movie. It is more focused on how the people he invited to the concert are reacting to meeting him and being given an opportunity to attend the concert. These patrons they show are not funny at all. The only good thing about the movie is the concert footage. My only gripe about that is that they don't show enough of the concert. For some artists you may get a full song but for most it was just like clips of their performance. You can tell it was a dope hip hop concert, due to the line up. I just wish they showed more of it.

reviewText: Dave Chappelle has been out of the media spotlight for some time now, and it really is sad.  Just one month after signing a $50 million dollar contract with Comedy Central, Dave Chappelle put together a rap/jazz/hip-hop concert in a little niche of Brooklyn, New York, and director Michael Gondry (Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind) and producers Bob Yari (Crash) and Chappelle himself got together to film this epic event.  Roger Ebert wrote, in his review, that it would be hard for someone, especially someone like Chappelle, to sign a $50 million dollar contract and then try to make it up to his loyal fans, but Dave Chappelle seems to do just fine with his plans.  He travels to Dayton, Ohio, where he lives a few miles away, and invited everyone from the owner of a convenience store where he buys his cigarettes to the entire Central State College Marching Band.  Race is no matter as blacks and whites pile on busses to travel to Brooklyn for a one day event, where Chappelle has provided them with free admission and free hotel rooms.  Despite rain, the concert goes off smoothly, combining musical and comedic talents like Erykah Badu, Mos Def, and the Roots, to name a few.  Chappelle is on and off the stage throughout the day, adding much needed laughter to the whole thing.  The film doesn't really have an organization like other documentaries (Werner Herzog's Grizzly Man comes to mind), but the concert isn't really that well put together either, and I think I like it better that way.  As I am not a fan of rap music, some of the acts seemed a bit dull, but I was surprised that I enjoyed much of the music acts, especially Erykah Badu, Jill Scott, and the return of the Fugees.  In the end, though, there is reflection from many of the performers, and they lend a strong insight to the culture of not only hip-hop, but the culture of music itself, and it also leads into topics of urban life, race (the scene with Wyclef Jean and the CSC marching band is wonderful), as well as many other things.  Much philosophical insight is provided by Roots drummer Ahmir "?uestLove" Thompson.  In the end, Chappelle has created more than a music festival; he has created a place where races can come together and listen to primarily African American music.  Even though most of the white people at the concert had confessed earlier to not liking rap (even the folks from the Broken Angel house), they still had a good time, and so did I.  It's not the greatest documentary that I have ever seen, but it really caught my attention and entertained me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this movie/concert production by the always brilliant and funny Dave Chappelle! The music is amazing, the commentaries and insightful, and Dave's jokes are appropriate (it's not a comedy or stand-up, he's just being himself). As a child of the 70s, I can appreciate this movie on so many levels. First of all, it is reminiscient of the movie concerts of the past (before You Tube, etc.). Secondly, the music and the choice of musicians is brilliant. However you want to categorize the artists (Hip Hop, Neo Soul, etc), they are the voice of now and conscious artists who commit not only to their artistry but also to being activist and supporters of the community. Thirdly, you get to see that Dave Chappelle is multifaceted and truly concerned with providing people with food for thought (not just jokes). Not that this matters but (like Talib Kweli) he is the son of collge professors. That said, he was, I'm sure, raised to be a "thinker" and a "doer." This concert was about him getting together with like-minded artists (Jill Scott, Mos Def, Talib Kweli, Erykah Badu, The Roots, Kayne West, Common, Dead Prez, and appearances by the legendary Big Daddy Kane, John Legend, the HBCU band of Central State, etc.) and getting together with us, the viewer. If you really listened to the message then you should have walked away from the experience feeling inspired.PS check out Erykah Badu's new CD coming out next week.New AmErykah, Pt. One: 4th World War

reviewText: It's as if someone downloaded one of my dreams. If I were to wish for a dream movie, this would be it. Not only does it have concert performances by some of my favourite hip-hop and neo-soul artistes ever - Kanye West, Common, Mos Def, The Roots, dead prez, Jill Scott and Erykah Badu, just to name a few - it's all presented by my favourite comedian ever (well, maybe apart from Chris Rock), the fantastic Dave Chappelle. The movie was shown on TV here a few weeks ago and after seeing it the once, I just knew I had to see it again and ordered the DVD immediately.Basically, we get to follow Dave as he returns to his hometown in Ohio to pass out invitations to his block party in Brooklyn, New York, including to an entire college or high school marching band. We get to see how he puts the show together and finally, we get to see the show itself. All the while, Dave peppers the movie here and there with his unique and inimitable humour.Watching the movie, I was reminded of several things: One, how powerful hip-hop music is and how I need to try and get out and see more concerts before I'm finally too old to do so; Two, how beautiful and talented black people are; And three, how I need to get a couple of CDs added to my collection, particularly Erykah Badu'sWorldwide Undergroundand Cody Chesnutt'sThe Headphone Masterpiece. I might actually get the soundtrack to the movie while I'm at it.But more than anything else, I was reminded of the fact that Dave Chappelle is probably one of the funniest, most engaging and most charming comedians of our time. I love him to death. He says it was the "best single day" of his career and I believe him. He really seemed to relish the opportunity to put the show together for people, many of whom might never have had the opportunity to attend such an event.It was also particularly interesting to see The Fugees on stage but while all three members gave a good performance, Lauryn Hill's heart didn't seem to be in it at all. Later on when she spoke to camera, her eyes just seemed dead.The DVD has some pretty cool extras. Extended music acts, (you can play the movie either in its original format or with the extended concert performances), A short documentary "The Ohio Players: The Bus Ride", and two others "September in Brooklyn" and "The Making of Block Party".I can't seem to get the subtitles to work on the main movie though but that's no big thing. I'm so glad I bought this DVD and can already see myself playing it over and over and never getting tired of it.
summary: I wish I could've been there too!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I got into a debate with a girl in my class about whether Dave Chapelle was funny. I never found his show amusing and when I saw the movie previews, I was determined that I wasn't going to see this movie. But when I caught a glimpse of Mos Def, Common, Talib Kweli, and Erykah Badu, I had to reconsider that idea. But today when I read on BlackNews.com that Big Daddy Kane was in the movie, that put the stamp on it for me! I went to the show two hours later and I am so glad I did. Chapelle put together the ideal concert. I am a huge fan of the artists above, and became fans of artists that I'd really not paid that much attention to before (Dead Prez). I knew Kanye and John Legend were gonna turn it out, and I love the documentary on the band.I didn't so much get into the scenes where we saw him invite people to the concert or the cracked-out lady from across the street. She was pointless considering she dogged out hip-hop without knowing the difference between rap and hip-hop. Somebody could've checked her on that, but her and her husband looked so strung out, I guess it wouldn't make a difference.I'm still a little peeved at Jill Scott for saying that "all women need men" in Essence magazine, so I couldn't give you an unbiased review of her performance.  Speaking of female performers, who else but Erykah Badu could have her wig fly off, show her crazy, wild hair, and then jump into the crowd? I LOVE Erykah Badu. When I saw Lauryn Hill...it kinda saddened me because I love her voice (especially when she sings "Killing me Softly"), but she forgot the words to the song at one point. It was about as embarassing as when she sang offkey on the BET awards. Personally, I'm not excited about the Fugees getting back together, because every time I see Lauryn, she acts kinda "crackish" (like Jamie Foxx would say). It's like watching Whitney Houston...the spark isn't there anymore. I respect her music of the past, but I wish she'd either get it together or bow out gracefully.I love Wyclef! I am crazy about that man's music. He could sing all day and I'd be all ears. Chapelle had some great folks in here and boy, Common is a cutie pie and talented too! I could watch this over and over again just to hear Lauryn sing the CORRECT lyrics to "Killing Me Softly," Erykah Badu's whole scene, Dead Prez spit that knowledge, and Mos Def croon to the crowd. Mos Def is one cool dude. As for Chapelle...I'm still not a fan of his comedy. He uses the n-word entirely too much and his jokes have no substance, but I gotta give him props for good music taste.  I was actually proud that he left the show to do some soul searching. I'd like to see him perform now because maybe he's learned that promoting stereotypes is not helping us as a people.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After seeing Dave Chappell's Block Party it didn't take me long ot realize that this isn't the same man that rose to fame in America with bigot and racist comedy sketches. So , if you are wanting to rent something reminicent of his show that aired on Comedy Central , you're better off renting Dave's earlier movies like " Con Air " , " Half Baked " or the " Dave Chappelle Show " dvd's. Although , most people will rent this film expecting the same ole same ole , and walk away dissappointed , I really enjoyed the film. I realized that Dave Chapelle is going through a spiritual and moral metamorphasis and it's truly a beautiful thing. This transformation is nothing new. Richard Pryor , Eddie Murphy , and just about every other successful artist, gets to a juncture and realize that there's more at stake than making or losing a career. It (celebrity) becomes a worldwide plateu , and it becomes necessary to measure the value of commercial and personal success and the importance of the types of messeges that you pass on to the world. Kinda like becoming a parent. Anyway , the dvd is highly entertaining and features fantastic musical guests like the Fugees , Commom , Mos Def , The Roots , John Legend , Jill Scott , and Eryka Badu. It's an enriching experience to travel with Dave Chappelle , as he spreads the word about a local block party and providing free tickets to the event. The music , the interaction , the comedic improv moments , and the enrgy is contagious. The most powerful aspect of this film ,lies in it's simple and innocent truth , that regardless of anything , people will still collectively get together and have a good time. Very good documentary. There is some adult language , so I don't recommend for kids under 16 yrs old.
Title: N/A
